issue.title: [ENH] Adding a Featureizer as _SeriesToSeriesTransformer

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When doing feature engineering, we want to calculate new features by means of any transformer and add them to existing ones. For this there is a need for a new transformer composition called `Featurizer` which gets any `_SeriesToSeriesTransformer` and appends the transformed data as new columns instead of overwriting the input data. `Featurizer` could either get a single transformer or a list of transformers (advanced implementation), this two cases look as follows.

Related: #1174

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen, ideally taking into consideration the existing toolbox design, classes and methods.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Use case when getting a single transformer:
```python
pipe = ForecastingPipeline(steps=[
    ("imputer", Imputer(method="mean")),
    ("minmaxscaler", Featurizer(TabularToSeriesAdaptor(MinMaxScaler(feature_range=(1,2))))),
    ("boxcox", Featurizer(TabularToSeriesAdaptor(PowerTransformer(method="box-cox")))),
    ("forecaster", AutoARIMA(suppress_warnings=True))])
pipe.fit(y=y_train, X=X_train)
```
In this case, the `boxcox` gets also the newly added features from `minmaxscaler`, whereas below the features are appended in parallel and not in sequence.
Use case when getting a list of transformers:
```python
pipe = ForecastingPipeline(steps=[
    ("imputer", Imputer(method="mean")),
    ("featurizer", Featurizer(
        ("minmaxscaler", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(MinMaxScaler(feature_range=(1,2)))),
        ("boxcox", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(PowerTransformer(method="box-cox"))),
    )),
    ("forecaster", AutoARIMA(suppress_warnings=True))])
pipe.fit(y=y_train, X=X_train)
```
The `Featurizer` would by default add the new columns by means of a suffix which is derived from the name of the transformer. Otherwise there could be a praram `suffix` and `prefix` so that user can also define this optionally.

**Additional context**
Pipelining

Any opinions @RNKuhns @mloning @fkiraly @ViktorKaz

body:
After some back and forth, I think the following would be a good/better pipelien design:

```python
my_pipeline = ForecastingPipeline(
    steps_y = [("y_trafo_name1", my_y_trafo1), etc, ("forecaster_name", my_forecaster],
    steps_X = [("X_trafo_name1", my_X_trafo1), etc],
    steps_y_to_X = [("y_to_X_trafo_name1", my_y_to_X_trafo1), etc],
)
```

`steps_y` is mandatory, other arguments are optional. The last argument of `steps_y` must be a forecaster, and the other arguments must be transformers that have `inverse_transform`.

What this would do:

In `fit`:
1. apply `steps_X` elements' `fit_transform` in sequence to `X`, to obtain `X_transformed`
2. apply `steps_y_to_X` elements' `fit_transform` individually to `y` and column-concatenate results to `X_transformed` (overwrite)
3. apply `fit_transform` of all transformers in `steps_y` in sequence to `y` to obtain `y_transformed`. Remember the fitted transformers (for `predict` below)
4. apply `my_forecaster.fit(X_transformed, y_transformed)` to fit `my_forecaster`

In `predict`:
1. apply `steps_X` elements' `fit_transform` in sequence to `X`, to obtain `X_transformed`
2. apply `steps_y_to_X` elements' `fit_transform` individually to `y` and column-concatenate results to `X_transformed` (overwrite)
3. apply `fit_transform` of all transformers in `steps_y` in sequence to `y` to obtain `y_transformed`.
4. apply `my_forecaster.predict(X_transformed, y_transformed)` to obtain forecasts `y_pred_transformed`
5. apply `inverse_transform` of all fitted transformers in `fit` step 3 in reverse order to `y_pred_transformed` to obtain `y_pred`
6. return `y_pred`

Notes:
* `update` is in analogy to `fit`, the difference is applying `update` of the forecaster instead of `fit` (and transformers' `update` if exist). Fitted transformers may have to be remembered.
* all `transformers` in `step_X` should recieve `y` (as input to `fit`/`predict` of the pipeline) as the `transform` `y` argument, although most will ignore this.
* all `transformers` in `step_y` and `step_y_to_X` should receive `X` (as input to `fit`/`predict` of the pipeline) as the `transform` `y` argument, although most will ignore this.

Advanced versions of this:
* the `forecaster` in `steps_y` does not need to be the last element, it can be in the middle. Then, `transform` of the transformers that come after it is applied to `y` (in reverse order) before passing it to `my_forecaster`. In `predict`, `inverse_transform` of the same transformers is applied to `y_pred` before returning.
* forecasters in `steps_X` and `steps_X_to_y` are applied to create/overwrite data in `X`

issue.title: [ENH] Train/test split and evaluation with disaggregated time series

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is.

I have a very specific forecasting use case that I solved elsewhere on my own. But only recently I discovered this fantastic library and obviously regret that it did not happen much earlier. I think that my use case could be a nice contribution.

The problem is the following. Suppose I have disaggregated data `y` and `X`. "Disaggregated" means that the forecasting frequency is, say, weekly, but the raw data is daily. My model extracts exogenous features from the past daily data (`X_train`) and uses an "auxiliary" model to forecast those features (`X_test`) which are in turn used in `.predict` method of the main forecaster. The current limitation of the library is that all the splitters and evaluation function assume that the data is already "regular", in my case weekly. This of course is not a problem if I only want to forecast once. But evaluation with `sktime.forecasting.model_evaluation._functions.evaluate` is impossible.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen, ideally taking into consideration the existing toolbox design, classes and methods.

I see two alternative solutions. Either a couple of new splitters alternative to existing ones, or a generalization of existing ones. The core change I need is replacing `np.arange` (e.g. in `train = np.arange(start - window_length, split_point)`) by pandas Series or DataFrame indices that are not directly linked to a regular grid. Function `sktime.forecasting.model_evaluation._functions._split` will have to be changed as well by rewriting this arithmetic: `test = np.arange(test[0] - fh.min(), test[-1]) + 1`. At the first glance it seems enough.

Given these changes I can easily imagine a forecasting pipeline where one of the steps would be an auxiliary model forecaster that would generate `X` on-the-fly. Next step would be data aggregation into, say, weekly frequency. And finally a main usual time series model for a regular frequency data.

I would love to contribute the solution myself. But I write this issue first in order to prevent unnecessary work if my solution violates some high level vision of the core developers. Please, let me know how do I proceed. Thanks!

issue.title: [ENH] Forecaster/transformer composition dunder methods

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Let's implement some dunder methods for forecaster and transformer composites (and, possibly, discuss design):

- [ ] `**` for applying a transformer to `X` into a forecaster, via `ForecastingPipeline`
- [ ]  `-` for `OptionalPassthrough` applied to a transformer
- [x] `|` for `MultiplexForecaster`
- [x] implement `MultiplexTransformer`
- [x] `|` for `MultiplexTransformer`

I should also mention existing constructs of the same kind, where we can look at (and possibly modify) existing design, and where we need to think about interactions:

* `*` tor chaining transformers, in a `TransformerPipeline`
* `+` for parallel application and output concatenation of transformers, in `FeatureUnion`
* `*` for chaining transformers to a classifier, in `ClassifierPipeline`
* `*` for applying transformers to input `y` and forecasting output of a forecaster, via `TransformedTargetForecaster`

One of the core design ideas for the dunders is to avoid having users search for the "right class", instead we want to use the parsing design pattern to create the right compositor class (or nested structure thereof).
